Abstract 
In the context of the Peruvian distribution sector, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant 
challenges in warehouse and inventory management, impacting their operational efficiency and customer satisfaction. 
This study addresses these issues by implementing a logistic model that integrates Economic Order Quantity (EOQ) 
and Systematic Layout Planning (SLP) to optimize operations in a Peruvian plastic distributor. The proposed model 
aims to enhance warehouse organization, streamline inventory management, and improve delivery performance. 
The research contribution involves a detailed application of the SLP methodology, combined with ABC analysis for 
product categorization and matrix tables for layout optimization. Additionally, the study incorporates EOQ for optimal 
order quantity determination and demand forecasting techniques to reduce stockouts. Key results demonstrate 
substantial improvements in operational metrics. Notably, on-time delivery rates increased by 18%, from 76% to 90%. 
Inventory stockouts decreased dramatically by 85%, reducing from 14% to 2%. The overall cycle time for order 
processing was shortened by 50%, from 60 minutes to 30 minutes. Furthermore, the effort required for picking and 
packaging activities was reduced by 33%, from 20,620 kg-mt to 13,820 kg-mt. These results indicate that the 
integration of SLP and EOQ models significantly mitigates the inefficiencies in warehouse management and inventory 
control, leading to enhanced operational performance and customer satisfaction in the distribution sector. 
Keywords 
Warehouse Management, Systematic Layout Planning, On time delivery, Plastic Distributor, EOQ

Efficient warehouse management is crucial for organizations involved in the selling and storage of various items. 
Likewise, these organizations necessitate effective inventory management. According to the National Institute of 
Statistics and Informatics, 98.6% of companies in Peru are classified as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

Abstract 
In the context of the hydrocarbon sector, which is crucial for the global and regional economies of Latin America, 
significant issues were identified in the operational efficiency of fuel supply terminals. These challenges included 
deficiencies in machine maintenance, lack of process standardization, and congestion in dispatch areas, negatively 
impacting productivity and increasing operational costs. This situation highlighted the need to apply method 
engineering techniques to optimize processes and improve operational efficiency. The contribution of this research 
consisted of developing and implementing a process improvement model based on method engineering to increase 
productivity in the dispatch area of a fuel supply terminal. The proposed model included stages of process selection, 
detailed diagramming, analysis and development of a new method, implementation, and control. These stages allowed 
for the identification and elimination of redundant activities, optimization of loading times, and improved resource 
utilization. The most outstanding results of implementing the new method included: a reduction in total process time 
from 77 to 62 minutes, representing a 19.48% improvement; an increase in the man-machine utilization percentage 
from 85% to 91%; a significant decrease in the waiting times for tanker trucks; and an improvement in operational 
efficiency, reaching a maximum efficiency of 98% on high productivity days. These indicators demonstrated that the 
application of method engineering effectively resolved the identified problems, increasing the productivity and 
efficiency of the fuel dispatch area. 
Keywords 
Engineering methods, productivity, dispatch, cisterns, supply.

The hydrocarbon industry is a key sector for the global economy, especially in regions with high levels of energy 
consumption. Globally, this industry is characterized by its crucial role in power generation, transport and 
manufacturing, being a primary source of fuel for various productive sectors (Tamayo et al., 2015). In Latin America, 
the hydrocarbon sector has had a significant influence on economic and social development, providing employment 
and generating significant income for producing countries (Palma, 2022). Peru is no exception, as its economy is 
heavily dependent on the production and marketing of hydrocarbons. The country has seen a growth in demand for

6. Conclusions 
The main findings of the study indicate that the application of engineering methods in the fuel dispatch area of a 
supply terminal significantly increased productivity. The implementation of operations diagrams, route diagrams, and 
multiple activity diagrams allowed for the identification and elimination of bottlenecks, reduction of waiting times, 
and improvement of the efficiency of the tanker loading process. Specifically, a 45% reduction in total dispatch times 
and a 19.48% improvement in operational efficiency were observed. Additionally, the redistribution of tasks and the 
elimination of redundant activities contributed to better utilization of human and material resources. 
 
The importance of this research lies in its contribution to improving operational efficiency in a critical sector of the 
economy, such as hydrocarbons. In a context of growing fuel demand and the need to optimize resources, the findings 
of this study offer practical and effective solutions to increase productivity and reduce operational costs. Furthermore, 
by improving efficiency in fuel dispatch, the study promotes a more sustainable and safer operation, which is crucial 
for the long-term competitiveness and sustainability of the sector. 
 
The contributions to the field of study are significant, as this work demonstrates the applicability and effectiveness of 
methods engineering techniques in a complex industrial environment. Implementing these methods not only improves 
specific processes of fuel dispatch but also establishes a reference framework that can be adapted and applied in other 
industrial sectors facing similar challenges. This methodological approach, supported by quantitative and qualitative 
data, reinforces the importance of efficient management of operational processes and the continuous pursuit of 
improvements. 
Finally, some final observations and suggestions for future studies are offered. The research highlights the need for 
constant monitoring and periodic re-evaluation of the implemented methods to ensure their continuous effectiveness. 
It is recommended to apply emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and real-time data analysis, to 
identify new improvement opportunities and further optimize processes. Additionally, future studies could explore the 
integration of environmental sustainability practices in the fuel dispatch process and evaluate the long-term impacts 
of the implemented improvements in terms of safety and operational efficiency.

Industry 5.0 Perspectives on the Trustworthiness of Novel 
Multimodal Language Models 
Alfonso E. de la Fuente Ruiz 
European Science Foundation  
C. Valenciana, Spain 
alfonsodelafuenteruiz@yahoo.es 
  
Galia Novakova Nedeltcheva  
Politecnico di Milano 
Milan, Italy  
galia.nedeltcheva@fondazione.polimi.it
Abstract 
 
The present paper aims to provide a multifaceted exploration of trends and challenges for ethical and trustworthy 
Multimodal Language Models. Firstly, by offering a perspective on the most prominent developments around these 
models, including Neural Networks, Transformers, Generative AI, and Foundation Models. Secondly, 
we explore Multimodal Language Models and their paradigms, including multimedia datatypes for both input and 
output, domain and industry-specific datasets, emerging tools, concepts and techniques, personalized AI systems, and 
energy-efficient computing paradigms. Then we reflect on emerging challenges for responsible AI, including 
alignment, inductive inference, ethical use, job replacement, jailbreaks, computability, open-sourcing, privacy, 
intellectual property, fair-use, or international regulation. Moreover, we explore their application from an Industry 5.0 
perspective across various fields, exemplified by critical areas like Health and Diagnostic Decision Support Systems, 
Job-matching, Cybersecurity, and AI-Human Collaboration. Finally, we draw conclusions and suggest technical 
mitigation strategies from a designer’s standpoint. 
Keywords  
Artificial Intelligence, Trustworthiness, Industry 5.0, Multimodal AI, Multimodal Language Models 
 
1. Introduction 
In the context of Industry 5.0's human-centricity and AI-enabling technologies, we conduct a comprehensive 
exploration of the trustworthiness of Large Language Models (LLM) and Multimodal Language Models (MLM), 
identifying emerging paradigms and application fields, while proposing solution and mitigation strategies for their 
uncertainties and challenges with an emphasis on multimodality and reliability in a rapidly evolving landscape. For 
this purpose, we have curated a database of more than three hundred peer-reviewed papers and similar number of 
online sources and other materials, like Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems documentation, GitHub repositories, and 
legislative developments worldwide. Historically, the field of AI has had numerous contributors for over  a century, 
from Santiago Ramón y Cajal’s studies on the neuron in the late 19th century to Leonardo Torres Quevedo's Chess-
Player automata in 1912, through Alan Turing’s results on computability, Shannon’s mathematic theory of 
communication, and various other studies before the so-called “AI winters” by the likes of Gödel, Chaitin, Wiener, 
Schützenberger, Solomonoff, Kolmogorov, Rosenblatt, McCullough, Pitts, Chomsky, or Minsky, on cybernetics, 
generative grammars, inductive inference, neural networks, formal language, or the theory of mind. Their results 
underpin many modern statistical models, including autoregressive language models like Generative Pre-Trained 
Transformers (GPT) that predict subsequent elements of a sequence given prior elements (Liu et al., 2024), and other
conclusion:
Proceedings of International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Operations Management 
 
© IEOM Society International 
their operation of potential fallibility is essential, as is enabling users to identify, tag, and mitigate (Yin et al., 2024) 
potential hallucinations, misinformation, and inaccuracies, advancing collectively towards a trustworthy knowledge 
economy.  Completely eliminating all obnoxious effects remains an elusive goal, although some techniques (Yin et 
al., 2024) are being developed behind and in front of their APIs, like using a second M/LLM to classify and filter 
outputs from the first or advancing in the sophistication of training and deployment procedures via RAG, fine-tuning, 
dataset curation, personalization, continuous learning, model benchmarking, and other methods. Addressing 
superalignment (Wu et al., 2023; Yin et al., 2024; Liu et al., 2024) is crucial for improving the social perception and 
acceptance towards AI, but, most importantly, for preventing unintended consequences and ensuring that MLM 
contribute positively to society, e.g., the “RegNLP” initiative (Goanta et al., 2023). Virtuous feedback loops and 
continuous evaluation are key (see tools like FiddlerAI, Deepchecks LLM, EvidentlyAI, or Giskard). 
In the AI-human collaboration process, while AI systems don’t yet possess emotions or consciousness like humans, 
and, therefore, the idea of AI developing feelings of wariness or distrust towards humans is not in line with our current 
understanding of AI capabilities and functioning, effective collaboration is built on certain key contributions that 
include provisioning MLM with a proper computational substrate to function, and high-quality, diverse datasets for 
accurate learning and decision-making. Humans also define clear objectives, ethical boundaries, and constraints for 
AI, ensuring their actions align with desired outcomes and ethical standards, although these must evolve as MMM 
become increasingly virtuous, capable of planning and self-improving (directly and because of human mediation), and 
progressively acquire both agency and autonomy. Continuous learning and feedback from humans help AI to refine 
their understanding and improve over time through reprogramming, in the classical, no-code, regulatory sense (Dolata 
et al., 2021), and across any other future or present multimedia modalities like physical training of embodied MLM, 
artificial vision (e.g., live/video feeds for lip reading, sign language, and wider body-language understanding), 
OpenAI’s text-to-video model Sora and subsequent related products (e.g., Google Veo), and generative 
video/3D/Web/source-code, especially when self-improving capabilities are to be present.  
5. Conclusion    
Industry 5.0 marks the era of flexible and adaptable technologies, prioritizing sustainability. Digitalization transforms 
industries, redefining production processes, leveraging human expertise, and altering the role of workers. To enhance 
trust in the reliability and ethical standards ("moral integrity") of M/LLM we should ensure that these systems meet 
the highest standards of rationality, explainability, security, stability, open-mindedness, and adaptability to culturally 
diverse perspectives (including but not limited to multilingualism), addressing the concerns of responsible security, 
privacy (for users and with regards to training data), and quality of service (inclusive of accuracy, availability, and 
responsiveness). In this manner we can bolster their ethical standing and public acceptance. Although different in 
their approach, complexity, and practical implementation, current MLM inference processes share the general 
principle of learning from data and making predictions with Solomonoff induction. In this context, Kolmogorov 
complexity plays a key role as a measure of the computational resources needed to specify an object, with the 
challenges that loss of information poses in cognitive processes such as memory compression. 
 
On the balancing of copyright protection, the key seems to be the concept of authorship and the degree and quality 
of human-made intellectual contributions, not very dissimilar from Shapley's value in economic theory for fair payoff 
allocation (Ali et al., 2023). Another pivotal factor in determining the legal status of such works globally is the 
determination of what is considered a “de minimis” amount of content, or even if defining a sharp cutoff criteria is 
appropriate within the context of AI-assisted creation e.g., in the intellectual and artistic spheres, or in the workplace. 
Some of the problems derived from the intrinsic lack of explainability and other issues with AI can be somewhat 
ameliorated to reduce errors and enhance safety, especially in the context of balancing automation and human expertise 
in sensitive areas like healthcare, through human-centered approaches, mistake-proofing poka-yoke methods for 
control of single points of failure, adaptive continuous learning, and stress-tested distributed redundancy with human 
supervision, drawing methods from fields like control & resilience engineering, fault-tolerant computing, systematic 
error reduction, and safety-critical systems. 
 
On safety and security, particularly in cybersecurity, privacy-related, and military applications, extraordinary global 
efforts are advisable, specifically targeted towards enhancing defensive capabilities, severely limiting autonomous 
offensive capabilities, guaranteeing civil rights, leveraging AI-enhanced diplomacy, e.g., trustworthy real time 
translation services, and de-risking in a Richardson's arms race model-aware manner. It is essential to incorporate 
advanced adversarial defense strategies during the model development and distillation process stages, as well as in 
and around their various interfaces (not only APIs). This includes practically auditable and properly monitored
references:
Proceedings of International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Operations Management 
 
© IEOM Society International 
curation of datasets and training method implementation, as well as rigorous testing against potential adversarial 
attacks, plus continuous refinement of models to guard against newly emerging threats, adapting to evolving ethical 
landscapes. In models where continuous learning is allowed, either directly or indirectly (e.g., via RLHF), robust trust 
management schemes and reliable data evaluation protocols should be implemented, especially if autonomous (with 
RLAI). We must consider the practical impossibility of preventing “bad actors” from (accidentally or intentionally) 
misusing MLM, but we can effectively impose some guardrails (considering the “Waluigi effect”) and curb online 
dissemination. The necessity of retaining and fostering a sufficiently dynamic research and innovation landscape 
recommends aiming for a balanced approach, potentially based on Open-Source Software (F/LOSS). Ethical and 
responsible use of M/LLM, transparency in AI processes, and conveniently audited adherence to legal and regulatory 
standards are essential. The key is establishing a balanced and mutually beneficial "win-win" interaction in the game-
theoretical sense by avoiding and preventing arms-race dynamics of distrust via robust oversight, enforcement of 
ethical standards, regulatory compliance, transparency in development, user/public education, and awareness of the 
data privacy, security risks, and societal impact -including that which is beneficial- of MLM. 
 
Technical mitigation strategies in MLM design: Some have been proposed for RNN-based models from the design 
and training stages, such as pre-programming, "teacher forcing", post-training quantization, quantization-aware 
training, batch normalization, regularizing nonlinearities, gradient scaling, using other architectures such as ResNets 
and activation functions like ReLU, or predictive coding and hyperdimensional computing, called to facilitate their 
use in IoT edge devices (Amrouch et al., 2022). Other potential research avenues include Caputo–Katugampola 
fractional-order methods (Cheng et al., 2023), Fractional Integral Neural Models, Quantum Convolutional NN, and 
some long-neglected analog computing paradigms, such as Spiking Neural Networks, e.g., Loihi-2 (Shrestha et al., 
2023) that can process signals and data in their native continuous form, reducing energy consumption and simplifying 
the network's architecture while improving its capacities. Note that optimizing resource use and energy efficiency not 
only involves the MLM’s own energy consumption (during training and inference, with metrics like cost-per-query 
and productivity/compute-per-watt) but also externalities like those of the broader impact of human societies. New 
platforms for speeding up inference are emerging, such as Groq’s Language Processing Units (LPU), and contextual 
windows are expanding rapidly (>1M tokens) to address issues like performance, forgetfulness, and personalization. 
 
Some other challenges remain for social capital growth, including the possibilities effectively affect and drive the 
development of MLM, the lack of simplified, empowered bottom-up process appeal procedures to a human in charge 
(e.g., in the workplace on automation-derived conflicts), addressing Moravec’s paradox, and imposing safeguards 
against sped-up automation of job replacement, and of knowledge, power, and wealth concentration dynamics 
resulting in inequality, inequity, unfairness, increased unrest of conflict, loneliness, distrust, and other social problems. 
Future implementation challenges for Industry 5.0 (Maddikunta et al., 2022; Khan et al., 2023) encompass security, 
data privacy, scalability, regulatory compliance, workforce re-skilling, and human-robot collaboration in the context 
of smart factories. Leveraging MLM-as-a-Service as tools to communicate and understand is certainly called to 
revolutionize countless spheres of everyday life, especially when applying any-to-any multimodality to translate 
(actually: ‘transform’) attentively and seamlessly from one domain into another and back. It is already clear that we 
are about to witness a new AI-powered scientific revolution, and, undoubtedly, MLM are at the forefront of this change. 
It is also quite clear that the responsible development and use of AI, done right, can be a driving force to significantly 
advance Sustainable Development Goals and the UN’s 2030 Agenda. 
 
Some of the limitations of the paper include the challenges of exploding research interest in the area during the last 
few years, which hints at the need for picking a specific methodology for an exhaustive and systematic literature 
review on the topic. Due to the limitations of time and length we were only able to point out some perspectives on 
Multimodal Language Models. Thus, in future research works we recommend presenting a deeper, more 
methodological explorative analysis of the most recent literature published since at least the onset of GPT-3, to spur 
more thorough insights for researchers and practitioners in the field of Industry 5.0 and AI.

Abstract 
The textile sector is highly competitive, so quality and efficiency are essential to improve the level of service of 
companies. For this reason, the implementation of a production model based on Lean Manufacturing, Total Productive 
Maintenance (TPM) and Simplified Logistics Planning (SLP) becomes a proposal for improvement for the 
optimization of companies' production processes. This paper will examine in detail the application of this improvement 
proposal through a case study and the impact that these models have on the efficiency, quality, and ability of the 
company to know customer demand. 
Keywords 
Lean Manufacturing, TPM, SLP, Textile, SMED 
1. Introduction
In today's dynamic business landscape, companies in the textile sector face increasing pressure to deliver high-quality 
products with shorter lead times while maintaining competitive pricing. To meet these evolving demands and stay 
ahead in the market, textile manufacturers must continuously seek innovative approaches to enhance their production 
processes and improve overall operational efficiency. 
In response to these challenges, the integration of Lean Manufacturing, Total Productive Maintenance (TPM), and 
Systematic Layout Planning (SLP) has emerged as a promising strategy to optimize production systems and increase 
the level of service in textile companies. Lean Manufacturing focuses on eliminating waste, TPM aims to maximize 
equipment effectiveness, and SLP enhances facility layout to facilitate smooth workflow and resource utilization. 
This paper presents a comprehensive production model that leverages the principles of Lean Manufacturing, TPM, 
and SLP to enhance the level of service in a textile manufacturing company. By combining these methodologies into 
an integrated approach, the aim is to create a synergistic framework that addresses key inefficiencies, reduces lead 
times, and improves overall productivity. 
1.1 Objectives 
The objectives of this paper revolve around the development of an integrative project aimed at enhancing the 
production process within the textile sector through the implementation of Lean Manufacturing, Total Productive 
Maintenance (TPM), and Simplified Logistics Planning (SLP). Specifically, the paper aims to achieve several key 
objectives. Firstly, it seeks to establish a comprehensive understanding of the project's background and the current

6. Conclusion  
With a cause-effect analysis of the identified problem, it was possible to determine three main causes that affect the 
Service Level, these being the low quality of the product, the non-compliance with the delivery time and the non-
compliance with the delivery quantity. Likewise, a Pareto diagram identified that the first two were the ones with the 
highest weight on the analyzed indicator with a total weight of 83%.  
  
Through the elaboration of the state of the art related to the case study, the main tools to be applied to each of the 
causes of the problem encountered were identified and determined. These tools are SLP to reduce process travel 
distances, SMED to eliminate times external to the use of the machine and thus optimize the key process that is the 
manufacture of garments, standardization to equalize the work done by all operators and thus reduce time and quality 
problems; and, finally, TPM, to reduce machine failures, thus improving product quality and reactive maintenance 
downtime.   
  
With the implementation of the proposed tools and through a simulation of the production process, it was possible to 
identify significant improvements in the different stages. In total, it was possible to increase the level of service from 
72% to 91%. This is due to the reduction of the travel of 25.7m in SLP, of times with SMED of 4.9 minutes of set up 
and with the standardization a reduction of 1.9 minutes per garment. 
  
As part of the stakeholder analysis, it was necessary to focus on the impacts of the activities on them. One of the most 
important is the environmental and health impacts, in which it was possible to identify that the most aggravating 
activity for both factors is that of printing due to the emission of polluting odors.   
  
Based on the financial analysis carried out for the investment of the improvement, this proposal is quite profitable 
since it has a positive NPV of S/ 114,050.18 and an IRR value higher than the percentage of COK obtained. Likewise, 
the risk analysis was carried out with the @Risk tool, identifying that even within the pessimistic scenario, this project 
continues to be profitable.

Abstract 
The growth of the fast-food sector in Lima, driven by the demand for efficient and high-quality services, has created 
the need to optimize service times in these establishments. This study arises with the objective of addressing 
inefficiencies in service processes in a fast-food restaurant, using continuous improvement tools such as queuing 
theory, aggregate planning, and simulations with Arena software. 
The research focused on improving order handling times through the standardization of methods and times, aggregate 
production planning, and the application of queuing theory. A continuous improvement model was developed in seven 
stages, which included detailed time and method studies, flow determination and time standards, and validation 
through simulations. 
The most notable results included a significant reduction in average order handling times from 23.14 minutes to 19.18 
minutes, which nearly doubled the total number of orders attended from 679 to 1,397. Additionally, the queue size 
and the number of customers leaving the line drastically decreased from 785 to 75 customers. Furthermore, revenues 
increased from 17,128 soles to 35,522 soles, demonstrating a remarkable improvement in operational efficiency and 
customer satisfaction. These indicators highlight the effectiveness of the proposed model in optimizing service times 
and increasing competitiveness in Lima's fast-food sector. 
. 
Keywords 
Continuous Improvement, Queuing Theory, Aggregate Production Planning, Fast-Food Service Optimization 
1. Introduction
The global fast-food restaurant sector has experienced significant growth over the past few decades, driven by its 
ability to offer quick and convenient meals to a large volume of customers. Originating in the United States, fast-food

6. Conclusions 
The main findings of the study indicate that the application of continuous improvement tools in a fast-food restaurant 
in Lima significantly optimizes service times and operational efficiency. The implementation of a systematic process 
improvement model, including time and methods studies, queuing theory, and aggregate production planning, reduced 
the average order processing times from 23.14 minutes to 19.18 minutes. Additionally, the number of customers 
leaving the queue drastically decreased from 785 to 75, resulting in a notable increase in revenue from 17,128 to 
35,522 PEN. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the applied methodologies in enhancing service capacity 
and customer satisfaction. 
 
The research conducted is of great importance as it addresses one of the main challenges in the fast-food sector: 
efficiency in customer service. In a context where speed and service quality are critical for competitiveness, optimizing 
internal processes not only improves the customer experience but also increases business profitability. Furthermore, 
the application of continuous improvement techniques and efficient supply chain management contributes to 
operational sustainability, especially in such a dynamic and demanding market as fast food. 
 
The contributions to the field of study are significant. This work not only provides a methodology applicable to other 
fast-food restaurants but also demonstrates the effectiveness of combining various industrial engineering techniques, 
such as queuing theory, aggregate planning, and continuous improvement tools, to solve complex operational 
problems. The integration of these techniques allows for more effective resource management, a reduction in non-
value-added activities, and greater consistency in service quality, which are crucial aspects for any service operation. 
Finally, final observations and suggestions for future studies are offered. It is recommended to conduct further research 
exploring the impact of emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and automation, on process optimization 
in fast-food restaurants. Additionally, it is suggested to evaluate the applicability of this model in different cultural

Abstract 
Industry 5.0 is the latest revolution announced by the European Commission that focuses on human-centricity, 
resilience, and sustainability. Its goal is to encourage the usage of the assets human beings have in conducting certain 
jobs and tasks and combining that with technology.  This research focuses on Industry 5.0 and assessing if corporations 
are ready to accommodate the ideology, values and technologies that are associated. Utilizing a systemic literature 
review to deep dive into the literature related to Industry 5.0 and its predecessor Industry 4.0, we are able to identify 
factors that would be needed for companies to accommodate Industry 5.0. Identifying skills, tools, and additional 
resources relevant to Industry 5.0 are a necessity in the success of transitioning between revolutions. This information 
will be gathered through academic/scholarly journals that are currently accessible, there will be further research 
conducted via surveys to obtain input from industry professionals and subject matter experts. We hypothesize that 
despite the overlap in Industry 4.0 and Industry 5.0 corporations are not 100% ready to accommodate Industry 5.0. 
We hope that our findings will contribute to an increase in corporations taking steps to utilize the ideas related to 
Industry 5.0. We also hope that this research will provide clarity to the differentiation between Industry 4.0 and 
Industry 5.0 and bridge the gap, resulting in a successful implementation of Industry 5.0.  
Keywords 
Human-Centric, Industry 4.0, Industry 5.0

Abstract 
Industry 4.0 technologies are reordering the global industry structure, creating new markets, products, improving labor 
productivity, and driving growth in advanced economies. They challenge existing industries and support the big data 
that can help transform how people live and work.  Technologies such as Mechatronics and Cyber-Physical Systems 
(CPS) have enormous impacts on predictive maintenance, improved decision-making in real-time, real-time inventory, 
and improved flexibility among jobs.  These technologies have a great impact on the labor market by shifting most of 
the manual and low-skilled jobs to automation. This paper presents some innovative mechatronics projects created 
using simulation, modeling, control, and real-time design and testing. 
Keywords 
Robotics, Automation, IoT, Smart Factory, Smart Sensors. 
1. Introduction
Industries are an integral part of the country’s economy because they produce material goods that are highly 
automatized and meet the customer’s demands. However, due to the rapid increase in customer demand in the 21st 
century, companies need to enhance themselves by integrating modern technology. 
In 2011, Germany along with the federal government and universities was the first to come up with the concept of 
Industry 4.0 (Reis and Gins 2017). It was a revolutionary concept that aimed to improve products by rapidly increasing 
the production and efficiency of industries that manufacture the product. 
Starting from Industry 1.0, which took place in the 18th century, we can see the evolution of the industry going from 
stream power and mechanical production to Industry 2.0 in the 19th century, which was characterized, by electricity 
and mass production assembly line. Industry 3.0, which took place in the mid 20th century, consisted of industries 
that were equipped with semi-automation. Industry 4.0 is a transition from 3.0 which integrates the Internet of Things 
in existing industries to a cyber-physical system that increases the overall performance of the industry. The evolution 
of the industry from 1.0 to 4.0 is depicted in a diagram in Figure 1 (Dilmé and de Huet 2021).

6. Conclusion 
In this paper, case studies of mechatronics projects have been presented which show how they can contribute to 
preparing students for the new industrial landscape. Mechatronics projects are highly effective in preparing students 
for Industry 4.0 by providing hands-on experience and fostering skills that are directly relevant to the modern industrial 
landscape. 
 
By engaging in these types of projects, students not only build their technical expertise but also develop the ability to 
innovate and adapt, which are essential traits for thriving in Industry 4.0. These projects provide a comprehensive, 
hands-on learning experience that integrates interdisciplinary knowledge, fosters technical proficiency, and 
encourages innovation. By working on mechatronics projects, students gain practical exposure to advanced 
manufacturing technologies, automation, IoT, cyber-physical systems, and data analytics—key components of 
Industry 4.0. 
Educational institutions should continue to evolve their mechatronics programs to align with the latest Industry 4.0 
trends and technologies. By doing so, they will produce graduates who are well-equipped to lead and succeed in the 
rapidly changing industrial landscape, contributing to the advancement of smart manufacturing and beyond. 
In summary, mechatronics projects are an indispensable part of engineering education, bridging the gap between 
theoretical knowledge and practical application, and ultimately preparing students for the challenges and opportunities 
presented by Industry 4.0.

Biographies  
Claudio Campana is an Applied Assistant Professor in Mechanical Engineering in the College of Engineering 
Technology and Architecture (CETA) at the University of Hartford appointed on August 2019. Recently he has been 
promoted to Applied Associate Professor starting August 2024. Prior to this Mr. Campana was a Research Engineer 
at the CETA’s Engineering Applications Center (EAC) from 1999 to 2019. He received his Master of Engineering 
degree in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Hartford in 1997 and his Bachelor of Science degree in 
Mechanical Engineering from Boston University in 1992. His areas of research include Computer Aided Design and 
Manufacturing, Online inspection/supervision of manufacturing processes, and Mechatronics Design and 
Instrumentation. He has undertaken numerous projects with industry, which include laser and vision-based non-
contact instrumentation for inspection of manufacturing processes and mechatronic instrumentation for test systems 
and motion control for rehabilitation devices. His research includes grants from NASA CT Space Grant Faculty

Improving Surgical Outcomes: Developing a Machine 
Learning Spine MRI Triage Tool 
Satyar Foroughi, Gerardo Torres, Edward Ventura, Mansooreh Mollaghasemi and Dr. Luis 
Rabelo 
Department of Industrial Engineering and Management Systems 
University of Central Florida, 4000 Central Florida Blvd, Orlando, USA 
Mansooreh.Mollaghasemi@ucf.edu, Luis.Rabelo@ucf.edu, 
Anthony.Mango@orlandohealth.com  
Abstract 
For patients suffering with back pain, getting a consultation appointment with a spine surgeon is sometimes a time-
consuming procedure that involves patients having to wait up to 12 weeks between MRI tests and interactions with 
orthopedic doctors to determine if they are candidates for surgery. Notable problems include incorrect referrals, which 
result in many patients being referred to surgeons for unneeded spine surgeries. One of the largest Hospital Systems 
in Florida asked us for a machine learning tool to assess spine MRI scans, identify regions of spinal stenosis, and 
produce a probability score suggesting the possibility of surgery being required to resolve these issues.  Three major 
problems that require quick attention confront the existing approach for ranking individuals with lumbar spine pain in 
the lower back. Initially, orthopedic spine surgeons take a long time to evaluate patients who might not require surgery. 
Second, the success rates of roughly 60% for spine surgery in treating this kind of pain are less than ideal. Finally, the 
procedure is challenged by prolonged patient wait periods, which strain orthopedic spine doctors' schedules and 
postpone treatment.  Developing a proof-of-concept model and formulating a comprehensive long-term project 
management approach are the two primary goals of the project. Reducing patient wait times, maximizing surgeon 
schedules, and protecting the system's intellectual property are among the objectives. Our project leverages 
advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) to optimize decision-making processes in the medical field, particularly in 
determining the necessity of spine surgery from MRI images. Our aim extends beyond mere image classification; we 
strive to enhance the entire patient care system, from initial consultation to potential surgery, by integrating AI to 
improve efficiency, reduce costs, and optimize resource allocation. Our machine learning model is built on the 
principles of deep learning, utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to process and analyze MRI images. 
By leveraging the layered architecture of CNNs, we enable the model to automatically learn and extract hierarchical 
features from the images. This deep learning approach allows our model to identify complex patterns and nuances in 
the medical images, improving the accuracy of our predictions and supporting more informed decision-making in 
spine surgery assessments. This model holds the potential to transform healthcare by providing quicker, more accurate 
diagnoses and ensuring timely interventions. As AI technology continues to evolve, our approach will adapt to 
incorporate new research and advancements, ensuring its continued relevance and effectiveness.  Implementing our 
machine learning spine MRI triage tool at Orlando Health is projected to significantly enhance their economic 
performance over the next five years. By improving efficiency and resource allocation, the weekly revenue is expected 
to grow from $2.6 million to $3.28 million. The ML model will save approximately $1 million annually in surgical 
wages by reducing unnecessary assessments and surgeries. Additionally, the tool will generate an estimated $192 
million in new surgical growth by accurately identifying and prioritizing candidates for surgery. Enhanced patient 
satisfaction and loyalty, driven by quicker and more accurate diagnoses, will contribute an additional $2 million 
annually. Furthermore, by minimizing human errors in documentation, the tool is projected to save $1 million annually 
in reimbursement loss prevention. In total, these improvements amount to an estimated value of $196 million over 
five years in cost savings and revenue growth. This demonstrates a substantial return on investment, underscoring the 
financial viability and transformative potential of our AI-driven approach in the medical field.  
Keywords 
Machine Learning, Spine MRI, Triage Tool
